content.content:
The STAR method is a way to answer interview questions about how you’ve handled past situations. STAR stands for Situation, Task, Action, and Result.

Interviewers are trying to figure out whether you’ll be successful if they hire you. One way they do that is to ask for examples of how you’ve dealt with challenges and successes.

content.heading: When to use the STAR method
content.subheading: The STAR method is great for responding to things like:
items: “Tell me about a time when you disagreed with your supervisor.”
“When you were assigned a recent project, what were the first steps you took to get up to speed?”
“Tell me about your biggest professional accomplishment.”
“What’s the biggest mistake you’ve made at work?”

content.subheading: With the STAR method, your answer to questions like these will include the:
items: Task — What you were responsible for
Action — What you did in the situation

content.content: In the next section, we’ll highlight some of the things to keep in mind as you try out this approach.

items: Prepare ahead of time. It’s best to practice answering common interview questions before an interview. (Congrats! By reading this, you’re well on your way.)
Ask for a moment to think. Questions about past experience are meant to be thoughtful ones. So if you need a minute, go ahead and ask for it.

Identify the goal of the question. It’s helpful to figure out what the interviewer wants to learn about you. Some common themes are teamwork, disagreement or conflict, and how well you think on your feet.

It’s OK to admit mistakes. Everyone makes mistakes, and interviewers know this. When they ask how you’ve handled a mistake, what they really want to know is what you’ve learned from it. Own up to what went wrong and then focus on how you moved forward.
Limit details to need-to-know context. Give the interviewer just enough information about the situation to understand what you were dealing with.
Make the results count. Be as specific as you can about the outcome of the example you’re sharing.
Keep it short. Aim for 1 to 2 sentences for each part of the STAR.

content.content: Can you explain a mistake you made and how you reacted to it?

One time, I mixed up the packing labels on 2 packages for customers. I needed to correct the problem without angering the clients. I called them both up, apologized for the mix-up, and provided them with shipping labels with the correct addresses. I also gave each of them a small gift certificate to use on a future order. The customers were both satisfied and will return and shop with us again. (Source: zety.com)
Tell me about a time when you had to juggle a lot of priorities.

Last month was the end of our fiscal year. We had several projects that had to wrap up, and I was assisting with 3 of the biggest deliverables. I divided up each day into blocks so that I could focus on one thing at a time. Of course I had to be flexible when meetings would come up, but the structure really helped me stay on top of things. We finished all 3 projects in time, and the clients were very pleased.
Pick a question to start with. You can take one of the ones listed above or choose your own. Just make sure that it’s a question or prompt that asks you to share a past experience.

questions.title: What question are you choosing to answer?
What are 3 possible examples you could use?
Choose one example. Describe the situation. (Tip: Make sure to tie it clearly to the question.)
What was your role or responsibility in the situation?
What actions did you take in response to the situation?
What was the result or outcome? (Tip: Be as specific as you can.)
Now write your full response here.

content.label: Zeti: First example of an interview response

content.content: Practice answering a few common interview questions using the STAR method. Once you have it down, ask a friend to role play an interview with you. Just remember to ask them to shake up the order of the questions so that you have to think on your feet a bit!
